document.masterDocTitle: A review of the small carrion beetles and the round fungus beetles of the West Indies (Coleoptera: Leiodidae), with descriptions of two new genera and 61 new species.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the small carrion beetles and the round fungus beetles of the West Indies (Coleoptera: Leiodidae), with descriptions of two new genera and 61 new species.

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of male
Aglyptinus
of the West Indies

paragraph.keyLead:
2(1). Occurs in Bahamas ; pale maculae at elytral apices; aedeagus ( Fig. 70 ) roundly arched dorsoventrally, sinuate before apex ............................
A. bahamensis Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Occurs in Greater Antilles; elytra usually without pale maculae at elytral apices; aedeagus not roundly arched dorsoventrally and sinuate before apex ........................................................... 3
4(3). Small, length usually less than 1.5 mm ; eyes and wings reduced ............................................... 5
— Larger, length usually greater than 1.5 mm ; eyes large, wings fully developed ........................ 6

5(4). Eyes and wings strongly reduced; aedeagus ( Fig. 78, 79 ) short and broad, dorsoventrally angulate near base; parameres absent .............................................
A. minutus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Eyes and wings slightly reduced; aedeagus ( Fig. 72, 73 ) elongate, slender, evenly curved dorsoventrally; parameres present ................................
A. biseriatus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

6(4). Antennae long, reaching base of pronotum; aedeagus ( Fig. 74, 75 ) strongly arched, apex abruptly narrowed, downturned .................................................
A. capitaneus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Antennae shorter, not reaching base of pronotum; aedeagus weakly to moderately arched, apex not downturned .......................................................................................................................... 7

7(6). Aedeagus ( Fig. 80, 81 ) moderately, evenly arched dorsoventrally; apex rounded in dorsal view; extreme tip of apex upturned, sinuate in lateral view .....
A. sinuatus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Aedeagus ( Fig. 76, 77 ) weakly arched dorsoventrally, depressed before apex; apex acute in dorsal view .........................................................................
A. fortipunctatus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

9(8). Eyes strongly reduced, wings strongly reduced; aedeagus ( Fig. 90, 91 ) evenly arched dorsoventrally, abruptly narrowed apically in dorsal view ..................
A. parvoculus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Eyes not strongly reduced, wings at least one-half narmal length; aedeagus not evenly arched dorsoventrally and abruptly narrowed apically in dorsal view .............................................. 10

10(9). Aedeagus ( Fig. 84, 85 ) short and broad, weakly angled dorsoventrally; in dorsal view, widened before apex ................................................................................................
A. jamaicensis Peck

11(10). Yellowish macula at apex of each elytron; aedeagus ( Fig. 88, 89 ) strongly arched dorsoventrally; apex narrowly rounded in dorsal view .............................
A. maculus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.
— Elytra not maculate; aedeagal apex acute in dorsal view .......................................................... 12

12(11). Aedeagus ( Fig. 82, 83 ) moderately arched dorsoventrally, depressed before down-turned apex; apex broad in dorsal view .......................................................................
A. dimorphicus Peck

— Aedeagus ( Fig. 86, 87 ) strongly arched dorsoventrally, apex upturned; apex narrow in dorsal view ...............................................................................
A. hemipterus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

13(8). Male metasternum with short median longitudinal carina in posterior half. Occurs on Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands .................................................................
A. puertoricensis Peck
— Male metasternum not carinate. Occurs on Hispaniola ............................................................ 14

14(13). Eyes strongly reduced; wings strongly reduced; maxillary palps elongate, penultimate palpomere broadly expanded; aedeagus ( Fig. 98, 99 ) with parameres absent .............................................. ................................................................................................
A. longipalpus Peck and Cook

— Eyes and wings not reduced; maxillary palps not elongate, penultimate palpomere not broadly expanded; parameres present ................................................................................................... 15

15(14). Aedeagus ( Fig. 94, 95 ) strongly arched dorsoventrally, angulate at middle, apex not drawn out in lateral view .....................................................................
A. angulatus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.
— Aedeagus roundly arched dorsoventrally, apex drawn out in lateral view ............................... 16

16(15). Aedeagal apex in dorsal view ( Fig. 97 ) acute .......................
A. grandis Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

18(17). Minute species, total length 1.2 mm ; head and pronotum impunctate (after Hlisnikovsky 1964 ). Aedeagus unknown ......................................................................
A. guadelupensis Portevin

— Larger species, total length 1.5–2.0 mm; head and pronotum finely, sparsely punctate. Aedeagus ( Fig. 102, 103 ) roundly arched dorsoventrally; apex rounded in dorsal view ............................ ...........................................................................................................
A. kaszabi Hlisnikovsky

19(17). Occurs on Dominica . Aedeagus ( Fig. 104, 105 ) strongly, roundly arched dorsoventrally, with depression before apex; apex truncate in dorsal view ....
A. dominica Peck and Cook
, n.sp.
— Occurs elsewhere in the Lesser Antilles. Aedeagal apex not truncate ...................................... 20

20(19). Occurs on Martinique . Aedeagus ( Fig. 106, 107 ) evenly, roundly curved dorsoventrally; flattened and narrowly rounded at apex ..............................
A. martiniquensis Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Occurs elsewhere in the Lesser Antilles. Aedeagal apices not evenly, roundly curved dorsoventrally; not flattened and narrowly rounded at apex ........................................................................... 21

22(21). Minute, length 1.1–1.2 mm ; aedeagus ( Fig. 110, 111 ) short and broad, angulate dorsoventrally at basal third; not constricted before apex ..............................
A. parvus Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Larger, length more than 1.4 mm ; aedeagus ( Fig. 108, 109 ) roundly arched dorsoventrally; in dorsal view, constricted before apex ......................................
A. luciae Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

23(21). Occurs on St. Vincent . Aedeagus ( Fig. 114, 115 ) elongate, slender, moderately curved dorsoventrally, with apical third curved upward ............
A. vincentii Peck and Cook
, n.sp.

— Occurs on Grenada . Aedeagus ( Fig. 112, 113 ) shorter, more strongly, evenly curved dorsoventrally; apical third not curved upward .................................
A. grenadensis Peck and Cook
, n.sp.
